faqs.title: What is Immuni?
faqs.content:
Immuni is an app created to help us fight epidemics, starting with COVID-19. 
The app has a contact tracing feature. When users discover they have tested positive for the virus, Immuni allows them to anonymously alert people they have been in close contact with and who may also have been infected. By being informed promptly (potentially even before developing symptoms of the virus), these people can contact their general practitioner to discuss their situation. Doing so can prevent them from infecting others, helping to reduce the spread of the virus.

faqs.title: How does Immuni's contact tracing system work?
faqs.content:
Immuni informs users that they have been in close contact with a person who has tested positive by sending them an alert that includes advice on how to deal with the situation. 

Immuni can determine that a risky exposure has taken place between two users without knowing who those users are and where they met. The app doesn’t (and can’t) collect any data that would identify the user, such as their name, date of birth, address, telephone number, or email address. To determine the contact, Immuni uses Bluetooth Low Energy technology and does not use geolocation data of any kind, including GPS data. 

Here is a simplified explanation of how the system works. Let’s consider the example of two hypothetical users, Alice and Marco: 

When Immuni is installed on their smartphones, it emits a Bluetooth signal that includes a random code. It does this on a continuous basis. When Alice approaches Marco, their smartphones exchange these codes and store them in their memory, thus making note of that contact. They also record how long the contact lasted and the strength of the Bluetooth signal received, an approximate indicator of the distance between Alice’s and Marco’s smartphones.

The codes are generated randomly, and they don’t contain any information about the user or their device. The codes also change several times every hour, protecting user privacy even more. It’s not possible to trace the identity of the user from their random codes. 

Let’s suppose that Marco later tests positive for the virus. With the help of the healthcare worker who notified him of his positive test result, Marco is able to report this result to Immuni, sharing his random codes and alerting the people he has been in close contact with. 

For every user, the app regularly downloads the random codes shared by users who have tested positive for the virus. By doing so, it can check if any of these codes correspond with those recorded in previous days. In our example, Alice's app will find Marco's random code. It will check the length and the distance of the contact to evaluate the risk of infection, and, if necessary, it will notify Alice.

faqs.title: Does the app track my movements?
faqs.content: No. Immuni is unable to know where you go or who you meet. The contact tracing system uses Bluetooth Low Energy technology and does not collect geolocation data of any kind, including GPS data.

faqs.title: How is my privacy protected?
faqs.content:
In developing Immuni, we have taken many measures to protect you and your privacy. Here’s a list of some of these measures:
 
• The app doesn’t collect any data that could enable your identity to be traced. It doesn’t ask for (and can’t obtain) information such as your name, surname, date of birth, address, telephone number, or email address. 
• Your movements aren’t tracked or traceable in any shape or form. 
• The random codes that smartphones exchange via Bluetooth don’t contain information about you or your device. 
• These random codes change several times every hour, protecting your privacy even further.
• The data saved on your smartphone and the connections between the app and the server are encrypted.
• All data, whether stored on the device or on the server, is deleted when no longer relevant, and certainly no later than December 31, 2020.
• The Ministry of Health is the body that collects your data. The data is used solely with the aim of containing the COVID-19 epidemic or for scientific research.
• The data is saved on servers in Italy and managed by public bodies.

faqs.title: Is the code open source?
faqs.content: Yes, the code is open-source and is available on GitHub. This is the licence: GNU Affero General Public License version 3.

faqs.title: Why is it important to download Immuni?
faqs.content: With Immuni, we have an extra weapon to limit the spread of the coronavirus. The more people who download it, the more effective this weapon becomes.

faqs.title: What happens if the app is used by a limited number of people?
faqs.content: Even if the circulation of Immuni ends up being limited, it can still help save lives and contain the virus, especially when combined with other measures such as social distancing and manual contact tracing. Immuni has already notified numerous people of risky exposure to users who have subsequently tested positive. Thanks to this information, these people have had the opportunity to break the chain of infections. Doing so helps to limit the spread of the virus and likely saves lives.

faqs.title: How can I check if I am using the app correctly?
faqs.content:
Open the app and check that ‘Service active’ appears in the Home section. If this is the case, Immuni is already working correctly and you don't have to do anything else. If not, tap ‘Reactivate Immuni’ and follow the instructions to make the app work correctly.

A few other important tips to make sure Immuni is at its most effective:
• When you leave your house, always bring your smartphone with Immuni installed.
• Don’t disable Bluetooth.
• Don’t uninstall the app.
• When Immuni sends you a notification, read it, open the app, and follow the instructions. For example, if the app asks you to update it, download the latest version without delay. 
• If you’re notified of a risky exposure, follow the instructions and call your general practitioner immediately.

faqs.title: Does this app make medical diagnoses or provide medical advice?
faqs.content: Immuni does not and cannot diagnose. Based on your history of exposure to potentially contagious users, it makes recommendations about what to do next. But the app is not a medical device, and it’s certainly not a substitute for a doctor.

faqs.title: Where can I download Immuni? Which devices and operating systems are supported?
faqs.content:
You can download Immuni from the App Store or Google Play, depending on your smartphone. Check below to see if your smartphone supports Immuni.

→ App Store
Your iPhone must have iOS version 13.5 or later. Supported models: 11, 11 Pro, 11 Pro Max, Xr, Xs, Xs Max, X, 8, 8 Plus, 7, 7 Plus, 6s, 6s Plus, SE. 

Please update iOS to the latest version before downloading Immuni.

→ Google Play
 Your Android smartphone must check all three of the following requirements:
 • Bluetooth Low Energy
 • Android version 6 (Marshmallow, API 23) or later
 • Google Play Services version 20.18.13 or later
 
Please update Android and Google Play Services to the latest version before downloading Immuni.

faqs.title: Are the recommendations that the app provides reliable?
faqs.content:
The app's recommendations depend on the duration of your exposure to potentially contagious users and on the distance between your smartphones during that exposure.

This information is limited and can never be perfect, as Bluetooth Low Energy signals are impacted by various disruptive factors. As such, the app's assessments won't always be flawless. If the app recommends that you self-isolate, it doesn't mean you definitely have the virus. It just means that, based on the information the app has available, isolating yourself is the safest thing to do for yourself and those around you.

Therefore, it's crucial that you follow all the instructions provided by the app—for your own good, as well as that of your loved ones and everyone else. Please get in touch with your general practitioner right away if the app notifies you of a risky exposure.

faqs.title: My smartphone does not support Immuni. Why not? What can I do about this?
faqs.content: Immuni draws on the exposure notification system developed by Apple and Google. This technology is shared by many other countries (including Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, and dozens more), and it allows the app to work at its best on most devices. Due to technical limitations, this technology is not available on older versions of iOS, Android, and Google Play Services. If things change, we will immediately make that information public.

faqs.title: Does the app drain my smartphone battery faster or make it overheat?
faqs.content: You shouldn't notice any difference in your battery life. Immuni uses Bluetooth Low Energy, a low energy consumption technology. It's the same technology that keeps wireless headphones constantly connected to smartphones. The impact on the battery is minimal, and using the app doesn’t cause overheating or anything else out of the ordinary.

faqs.title: Can children use the app?
faqs.content: You must be at least 14 years old to use Immuni. If you’re between 14 and 18, you must have the permission of at least one of your parents or of your legal guardian. If that’s the case, please notify them immediately if you receive an alert notification that you have been in close contact with a person who has tested positive.

faqs.title: Can I access my profile from multiple devices?
faqs.content: No. With Immuni, you don’t create a profile like you’re used to doing with many other apps. Therefore, if you install the app on a new device, there’s no way for Immuni to understand that you’re the same user.

faqs.title: Is Immuni operated by the government?
faqs.content:
Yes. Immuni is the contact tracing app of the Italian Government. It is a collaboration between the Presidency of the Council of Ministers, the Minister of Health, the Minister for Technological Innovation and Digitisation, the Regions, the extraordinary Commissioner for the Covid-19 emergency, and the public companies Sogei and PagoPa.

For Immuni, the Italian government uses a perpetual and irrevocable license on all the code, graphics, text, and documentation, granted free of charge by Bending Spoons S.p.A.
Bending Spoons S.p.A. provided a documentation, design, and software development service, completely free of charge and without decision-making authority or access to user data, until October 13, 2020.

The instructions of the Italian Data Protection Authority were followed in developing the system, paying maximum attention to user privacy.

faqs.title: Do I need to pay to use Immuni?
faqs.content: No. Immuni is completely free of charge.

faqs.title: Can I decide not to use the app?
faqs.content:
Yes, the downloading and use of Immuni is voluntary.

Immuni is an important tool in the fight against the COVID-19 epidemic. The more that the app circulates, the more effective it is. We strongly recommend installing it and encouraging your friends, family, and colleagues to do likewise.

faqs.title: Immuni tells me that I’ve had a risky exposure, but I feel fine. What should I do?
faqs.content:
If Immuni has detected a risky exposure, you have been in close contact with a person testing positive for the virus in the last few days for more than 15 minutes. Therefore, you may have contracted the virus, without necessarily showing symptoms. 

Please play your part by following Immuni’s recommendations. This reduces the risk to you and your loved ones, and helps to avoid infecting others.

faqs.title: I have been to a place or with a person that I would like to keep private. Is my privacy at risk with Immuni?
faqs.content:
With Immuni, your privacy is protected. The app does not (and cannot) determine where and with whom you have been.

The system is based on Bluetooth Low Energy technology. It does not record or share information about you or your contacts, and it does not use geolocation data of any kind, including GPS data.

faqs.title: Do I need to sign up with my email address and password?
faqs.content: No. The app doesn’t collect any data that would make it possible to know your identity. For example, it doesn’t ask for (and can’t obtain) your name, date of birth, address, telephone number, or email address.

faqs.title: Does Immuni need to be in the foreground to work? Can I use other apps?
faqs.content: Immuni operates in the background, so the important thing is that your smartphone is turned on and Bluetooth is active. You can also terminate the app manually and use other apps as normal—as long as you have it installed on your device, you’re all set.

faqs.title: Do I need to keep my smartphone’s Bluetooth turned on all the time?
faqs.content: The exposure notification system is based on Bluetooth Low Energy, so Bluetooth must always be active for the system to detect your contact with other users.

faqs.title: I often keep my smartphone in airplane mode. Can I continue to do this?
faqs.content: Yes, as long as you still keep Bluetooth on. That way, Immuni will continue to work as intended. Also, remember to connect your smartphone to the Internet at least once a day, to allow Immuni to check for a risky exposure.

faqs.title: How much data traffic does Immuni consume?
faqs.content: Very little. Every day, the app downloads the random codes of users who tested positive for the virus to check if you have been in close contact with any of them, and the app notifies you if necessary. This consumes at most a few megabytes of data traffic per day—roughly similar to loading a page of a site with a few photos.

faqs.title: The app prompted me to update it: what happens if I don’t do so?
faqs.content: The updates aim to improve the effectiveness of the system, including fixing potentially critical issues. Therefore, it’s important to update your Immuni app when a new version becomes available. If the update is deemed necessary, the app will send you a notification. However, the decision of whether or not to update the app is ultimately up to you.

faqs.title: Can I use the app without Internet connection?
faqs.content: Immuni doesn’t require a continuous Internet connection. However, the app does need to connect to the Internet at least once a day. This is so that the app can download the information necessary to check if you’ve been exposed to potentially contagious users. Therefore, please make sure your smartphone is connected to the Internet at least once a day.

faqs.title: Does Immuni share or sell my data?
faqs.content:
Immuni's sole purpose is to help cope with the epidemic. The project is not for profit, and in no case will your data be sold or used for any commercial purpose, including profiling for advertising purposes.

The data is under the care of the Ministry of Health. Any sharing of the information collected is strictly for the purpose of scientific research, and only after its complete anonymisation and aggregation.

faqs.title: Can I change the language of the app?
faqs.content: The languages currently supported are Italian, English, German, French, and Spanish. The app uses the same language that’s set on your smartphone, where available. Otherwise, it uses English. Therefore, to change the language of the app, you’ll need to change the language of your device.

faqs.title: Does Immuni work in all countries?
faqs.content:
You can download Immuni from all over the world.

For security reasons, however, you need to be in Italy to upload your data if you test positive for the virus. 

Also for security reasons, you can’t connect to the server that allows you to download the random codes of positive users if you’re outside the European Union. On iOS devices, the exchange of random codes is disabled if you’re overseas.

At the moment, Immuni only detects contact with other Immuni users. At European Union level, work is being done to allow the various national contact tracing apps, including Immuni, to communicate with each other. This would make it possible to extend contact tracing to foreigners travelling in Italy and to Italians travelling abroad, without the need to download additional apps.

faqs.title: What is a 'one-time code' and how does it work?
faqs.content:
A one-time code is a ten-character alphanumeric sequence that is used only upon testing positive for the SARS-CoV-2  virus. It does not (and cannot) identify the user of the Immuni app.
When a user tests positive for the virus, you can decide to upload to the Immuni server the data necessary to anonymously warn users who have been in close contact with you in the last 14 days. To do this, the user must dictate the one-time code found in the appropriate section “report a positive result” of the app to the healthcare worker who has informed you of the result of their swab test, or to the telephone operator of the call center 800 91 24 91. 
The call center service is currently active only for some regions and autonomous provinces: Campania, Lombardia, Friuli Venezia Giulia, Molise, Trento, and only for those who have received the CUN (National Unique Code).
After the operator has validated the one-time  code, you can proceed to upload the positivity data. This is also called “unlocking” Immuni.

faqs.title: How and when can I upload my data?
faqs.content:
You can only upload your data if your test was positive for Coronavirus and you have a molecular swab test. The operation is voluntary and allows Immuni to warn the people with whom you have been in contact in the previous 14 days.
This operation must be carried out with the support of the health worker who communicated the positive result of the swab to you, or with the support of the call center operator 800 91 24 91, if you have taken the test in one of the regions or autonomous provinces in which the call center service is active: Campania, Lombardia, Friuli Venezia Giulia, Molise, Trento.

faqs.title: Which are the steps to report a positive result on Immuni?
faqs.content:
The healthcare worker of the prevention service who communicated to you the result of the molecular swab or the telephone operator of the Immuni call center will ask you to enter the "Settings" section in the App and choose "Report a positive result".
Immuni will show you a one-time code, a sequence of ten randomly generated characters.
Communicate this code to the operator, who will give you the authorization to continue
Click "Continue"
Immuni will show you a summary of the data that will be uploaded.
By clicking on "Upload data", the app will upload your data
Finally, you will be asked for permission to access the random codes saved on your device
The app will show you a confirmation message once the upload is complete

faqs.title: How does Immuni inform me that I have had a risky exposure? What should I do in that case?
faqs.content: If Immuni detects that you have been exposed to a possible infection, it will notify you. Please follow the recommendations you find inside the app, starting with contacting your general practitioner. There's no obligation to follow the recommendations, but we strongly encourage you to do so to protect your health, and that of your loved ones and the community.

faqs.title: Under what conditions does Immuni warn me of a risky exposure? At what distance and for how long must I have been in contact with a user who then tests positive for the virus?
faqs.content:
Immuni warns you of a risky exposure only if someone who has tested positive for the virus has been close to you for at least 15 minutes. That person must have Immuni on their smartphone and have chosen to report their positive result when the result of the swab was made known. Otherwise, no notification can be sent.

Immuni uses the strength of the Bluetooth signal to estimate the distance at which contact occurred. The parameters of the estimate come as close as possible to the directives of the Ministry of Health, which consider contact occurring at a distance of less than two metres as risky. Numerous calibration experiments have been performed to make the estimate as accurate as possible, but it can still present a margin of error. Moreover, it does not account for any barriers or protective devices present. Receiving an exposure notification does not occur without prolonged physical proximity to someone who has tested positive for the virus.

faqs.title: I've just updated iOS on my iPhone to a version that in theory should enable the use of Immuni. However, when I open the app, it tells me that a more recent version of iOS is required. What should I do?
faqs.content:
You’ve probably not completed the iOS update process. To update iOS, you must complete two steps:
1. Download the latest version
2. Install it

To download the latest version of iOS, you must be connected to Wi-Fi. Otherwise, the button to start the download will be disabled. Go to Settings > General > Software Update. If you've downloaded the latest version of iOS, but you haven't installed it yet, tap 'Install Now'. To verify that the installation has completed correctly, go to Settings > General > About. 'Software Version' should display version 13.5 or above.

faqs.title: I am asked to enter a credit card before downloading Immuni from App Store or Google Play. Is this normal?
faqs.content:
Immuni is completely free. You can download it without specifying a payment method.

If Apple or Google asks you for a credit card, it’s likely that you haven’t finished setting up your account yet. To download Immuni free of charge, proceed as follows:
• On the App Store, choose 'None' from the payment methods offered.
• On Google Play, choose 'Skip' when prompted for a payment method.

faqs.title: When I use the app on an Android smartphone, why am I asked to activate geolocalisation? Does it mean that the app has access to my location?
faqs.content: No, Immuni has absolutely no access to any geolocation data. On Android smartphones, due to a limitation of the operating system, the geolocalisation service needs to be enabled to allow Google’s exposure notification system to detect Bluetooth Low Energy signals and record the random codes of the smartphones of the users around you. However, as you can see from the list of permissions requested by Immuni, the app isn’t authorised to access any geolocation data (including GPS data). Therefore, it does not and cannot know where you are.

faqs.title: The message 'Exposure notification area changed' or 'COVID-19 exposure notifications no longer supported in your area' appeared on my iPhone. What does this mean?
faqs.content: This was an operating system defect that Apple has now fixed. Please update to iOS version 13.6 or later to prevent the message from reappearing.

faqs.title: Can I temporarily disable Immuni?
faqs.content:
Yes, you can temporarily disable Immuni (for example, while you are at work if you are a healthcare worker in contact with COVID-19 patients). Disabling Immuni means that your contact with other users is not recorded.

To temporarily disable Immuni, follow these steps:
• Open the app.
• Scroll down and tap 'Disable service' at the bottom of the Home screen.
• Follow the instructions.

Remember to reactivate Immuni as soon as possible by following these steps:
• Open the app.
• Tap 'Reactivate Immuni' at the top of the Home screen.
• Follow the instructions.

faqs.title: When I travel for work or leisure, do I have to change the province that I have provided to the app?
faqs.content: No, you don’t need to select a different province every time you leave the one you indicated when setting up the app. Immuni works the same way regardless of province. Your province of domicile information helps the National Health Service to prevent the onset of new outbreaks and estimate the adoption of the app throughout the country.

faqs.title: Can people with visual impairments use Immuni?
faqs.content:
Immuni was designed to be as accessible as possible to people with disabilities. The app supports VoiceOver (on iOS devices) and TalkBack (on Android devices), which read aloud what is displayed on the screen. This helps users with visual impairments to access all the app’s content and features with ease. 

Immuni does not currently support voice commands.

faqs.title: For how long is the one-time code valid? How much time do I have to upload my data?
faqs.content: The one-time code remains valid for 2 minutes and 30 seconds from when the healthcare worker begins validating it. This provides plenty of time to complete the upload process. However, if the code expires, you can repeat the upload process from the beginning, using a new one-time code generated by Immuni.

faqs.title: Immuni refers to 'random codes'. What are they?
faqs.content: Immuni associates a random code with each smartphone running the app. These are transmitted to nearby devices via Bluetooth Low Energy technology. When two users are in close proximity, their smartphones record each other’s random codes in their memory. This makes a note of that contact, and, if either of the two users later tests positive for the virus, the app allows them to report this and inform the other user of a risky exposure. For even greater privacy protection, the random codes change several times every hour.

faqs.title: Who are the healthcare workers that Immuni refers to?
faqs.content:
These are healthcare personnel from the Prevention Department of the local health authority or hospitals who normally inform someone by phone in the event of a positive swab test result. If the person who tested positive has Immuni installed, they can choose to report their positive test result. Doing so allows Immuni to warn users with whom they’ve been in close contact of the risk of infection.
To guide and enable the user in uploading data and in the unlocking of Immuni, it can be either the healthcare worker himself who communicated the result of the report, or a telephone operator of the call center dedicated to Immuni, reachable at the number green 800 91 24 91, for those regions where the service is already active: Campania, Lombardia, Friuli Venezia Giulia, Molise, Trento.

faqs.title: Can I hide a risky exposure notification and restore it later?
faqs.content:
Once you receive a notification warning you of a risky exposure, an additional warning appears within the app and suggests what to do.

The warning and suggestions remain visible within the app. In the event that you declare you are in contact with your doctor (by tapping ‘I have contacted the doctor’) or decide to hide the warning (by tapping ’Hide warning'), the warning and suggestions are hidden and no longer recoverable, to protect your privacy. We strongly advise against doing this, to avoid losing access to very important information.

faqs.title: After reporting my positive test result, how can I report to Immuni that I have recovered?
faqs.content: Your local health authority will ask you to do one or more swabs to confirm that you are no longer testing positive for the virus. When you receive confirmation of testing negative from your local health authority, you can update your health status within the app. Just tap 'Are you better?’, ‘Update your status’, then 'I am COVID-19 negative'.

faqs.title: I have an iPhone but despite being connected to the Internet and having Bluetooth enabled, Immuni does not work without a SIM card inserted. Why?
faqs.content:
Apple has activated a security measure that prevents the use of Immuni when you’re in countries other than Italy. To make sure that you’re in Italy, Apple verifies that the telephone operator is Italian. As such, a SIM card must be inserted in the smartphone for Immuni to work. On Android devices, however, Immuni works correctly even without a SIM card.

This limitation has been removed by Apple, starting with version 13.6 of the iOS operating system. If you want to use Immuni without a SIM card, we recommend updating your iPhone's operating system to the latest version.

faqs.title: Immuni displays a connection error message when I try to use it. What can I do?
faqs.content:
If you’re outside the European Union, it’s normal to receive an error message. Some features of Immuni may not be available.

If you’re connected from within the European Union, we recommend that you proceed as follows:
• Check that your smartphone is connected to the Internet.
• Connect from a mobile network. The problem may be due to an incorrectly configured Wi-Fi network.
• If you’re using a VPN, turn it off. The VPN may have assigned you an IP outside the European Union.

We remind you that the countries of the European Union are as follows: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Iceland, Lichtenstein, Norway, Switzerland, Vatican City, San Marino, and Principality of Monaco.

faqs.title: Immuni displays a connection error message when I try to report my positive test result. What can I do?
faqs.content:
For security reasons, it’s only possible to report a positive test result from Italy or neighbouring areas (France, Switzerland, Slovenia, Vatican City, and San Marino). If you’re connected from elsewhere, it’s normal for you to receive the error message. 

If you are connected from within Italy or a neighbouring area and you receive the error message, we recommend that you proceed as follows:
• Check that your smartphone is connected to the Internet.
• Connect from a mobile network. The problem may be due to an incorrectly configured Wi-Fi network.
• If you’re using a VPN, turn it off. The VPN may have assigned you an IP outside the European Union, which prevents you from performing this action.

faqs.title: What is meant by "unlocking" of Immuni?
faqs.content:
To notify the close contacts of the person who tested positive for Covid-19, it is necessary to send the disposable code to the Immuni server. Since the code is temporary, this operation must be done within a few minutes with the assistance of a health care worker from the Prevention Department who performed the swab or - for regions already registered for the service - through the Immuni call center. The operator checks the disposable code and authorizes the data to be uploaded.
The whole operation is commonly called "unlocking" of Immuni.

faqs.title: What is the CUN?
faqs.content:
The CUN, or National Unique Code, is a code that uniquely identifies the outcome of a molecular swab, be it positive or negative. It consists of 10 characters preceded by the suffix CUN-.
Through the CUN it is possible to contact the call center that supports the citizen for the unlocking of Immuni.

faqs.title: Is the CUN also needed when I contact or I am contacted by the health care worker of the prevention department?
faqs.content: No, the CUN is only used to request assistance from the call center.

faqs.title: Where can I find the CUN?
faqs.content: The CUN is sent by the Regional Health System directly to the citizen through one or more of the following channels, depending on the Region or autonomous province in which you were tested: SMS, EMAIL, APP OR REGIONAL PORTAL, FSE (Electronic Health Record), or it is transcribed in the swab report or isolation certificate. In any case, you can easily identify it because it is the only code that begins with CUN- and is followed by 10 characters.

faqs.title: What is the CUN for?
faqs.content: The CUN is used to independently proceed to report positivity through the Immuni app and to call center operators to verify the actual positivity of the person and support in the positivity reporting operation.

faqs.title: Who can unlock Immuni?
faqs.content:
Citizens who have already installed the APP on their mobile phones and who test positive for the molecular swab can proceed with the unlock of Immuni. This operation can be carried out in real time with the assistance of the health worker who communicated the result of the swab to the citizen, or directly through the Immuni app by entering the CUN code relating to the molecular swab. For any eventuality, the operators of Immuni call center 800.91.24.91 are available to guide you also in this unlocking operation via CUN.

Warning: GPs are not authorized to support the unlocking of Immuni

faqs.title: Can the general practitioner also help me upload the positive data on Immuni?
faqs.content: No, GPs (general practitioners)  are not authorized to support the unlocking of Immuni, but they can help you identify the correct behaviors if you receive a notification from Immuni, such as alerts when you have come into contact with a person who tested positive for Coronavirus.

faqs.title: When I call the call center, what information do I need to have in order to unlock Immuni?
faqs.content: To unlock Immuni through the call center, you must have the CUN (National Unique Code), your health card, the start date of symptoms (if you are symptomatic). And of course the Immuni app.

faqs.title: Why are all these steps required (CUN, Health Card, single use code) to unlock Immuni?
faqs.content: As a matter of safety and to avoid that, even unintentionally or by mistake, someone can communicate incorrect information relating to their positivity to Immuni, thus generating, as a consequence, a flow of incorrect notifications to all their contacts.

faqs.title: Can minors also use the call center unlocking service?
faqs.content: The parent of a minor over 14 may contact the call center to support the minor child in unlocking Immuni. The CUN will be communicated to the parent's mobile number.

faqs.title: What services does the call center 800 91 24 91 provide?
faqs.content:
The call center 800 91 24 91 provides general information regarding the Immuni app and, starting from 21 December 2020, also supports citizens in uploading positivity data and in unlocking the App. This new service was established by the Ministry of Health under article 20 of the decree-law of 28 October 2020, n 137.
The call center is dedicated to both citizens and healthcare professionals, with two different dedicated channels.

faqs.title: What type of test is needed to unlock Immuni?
faqs.content: At present, only molecular swab tests are recognized as valid. The antigen tests (or rapid tests) are therefore not currently usable for the unblocking of Immuni. The test must also be carried out in a public or private structure accredited by the regions or autonomous provinces. Non-accredited private facilities may in fact not communicate the outcome of the report to the regional health system.

faqs.title: How does the Immuni unblocking work through the call center?
faqs.content: When you call the call center, you will be guided to unlock Immuni: you will first be asked to communicate your CUN, through which the operator will verify your actual positivity; then you will need to communicate your Health Card number, through which your identity will be verified, and finally, by communicating the disposable code that you find in the "report positivity" section of the app, you will be authorized to enter your positivity data.

faqs.title: In which regions or autonomous provinces is the Immuni data upload and unblocking support telephone service active?
faqs.content: The service is active from January the 15th on the whole national territory. In Sardinia it will be active from January the 19th. In Calabria, Piedmont and the autonomous province of Bolzano from February  the 1st.

faqs.title: Will Healthcare Professionals Still be able to unlock Immuni?
faqs.content: Absolutely yes. The call center service does not replace the operators of the Health Prevention Departments, but supports them. Therefore, you can unlock Immuni even when you are called by the healthcare professional who informs you of the results of the test.

faqs.title: If I get a notification from Immuni, who should I call?
faqs.content: You can go to your GP, who will discuss the measures to be taken with you.

faqs.title: I did the molecular test in Lombardia, but I live in Lazio. Lombardy is one of the regions that has the support service for data loading via call centers, Lazio is not. Will I receive the CUN and can I contact the call center?
faqs.content: Yes, if you left your contact details when you were tested.

faqs.title: What do I do if the citizen has a CUN but it is not available on the TS system?
faqs.content: If the CUN number is not transmitted by the competent region or autonomous province, the citizen is invited to contact the health prevention department of his ASL for unlocking Immuni.
